 Outline keyboard_arrow_down Title Abstract Introduction Implication Conclusion All Topics Theology download Download Free PDF Download Free PDF Incorporating BAM at the Local Church Context of Nepal Yam Shrestha Uploaded (2025) | Journal: Yam Shrestha visibility  description 12 pages link 1 file description See full PDF download Download PDF 
 
 
 bookmark Save to Library share Share close Sign up for access to the world's latest research Sign up for free arrow_forward check Get notified about relevant papers check Save papers to use in your research check Join the discussion with peers check Track your impact Abstract Introduction I. Understanding BAM A. What does BAM mean? B. Biblical Value of BAM C. The purpose of BAM II. The Importance and Challenges to Incorporating the BAM in Nepal A. The Importance of BAM B. The Challenges to Incorporate the BAM III. The way of incorporating BAM IV. Implication Conclusion ... Read more Related papers Religion and Secularism in Contemporary Nepal Chiara Letizia , David Gellner Routledge Handbook of South Asian Religions, 2021 Between 2006 and 2017 Nepal transitioned from being an officially Hindu kingdom to an officially secular federal republican state. Although some Nepalis have upheld a model of secularism that would imply no connection between the state and religion, for most it implies that the state should support all religions equally. Through case studies (1) of conversion and the relation of Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity to the state and to Hinduism, (2) of diverse Hindu responses to secularism, and (3) of the controversy over animal sacrifices at the Gadhimai festival, the chapter examines the effects of the new concepts, propagated by the state especially since 2015, of secularism and of distinct religions and ethnic groups. download Download free PDF View PDF chevron_right Banishment of the B-word: interpreting ethnic and religious revival among the Tamang people of Nepal Jonathan Samuels European Bulletin of Himalayan Research (EBHR), 2018 Since 1990, an ethnic revival (Toffin 209: 25) in Nepal has seen members of janaj캐ti (indigenous nationalities) campaign for greater recognition and rights for their respective groups. Many anthropologists are strongly opposed to the way that activists project the identities of these groups as historical continuities. Questions about the antiquity and authenticity of their cultural and religious traditions also abound. The focus of this study are the Tamang, one of Nepals largest ethnic minorities. Recent changes in Tamang religious practices are considered within the context of the contemporaneous ethnic revival. After outlining the historical background of the current situation, in which some activists and anthropologists find themselves pitted against one another, this study argues that members of both groups are strangely united in their wish to distance representations of Tamang identity and religious affiliation from associations with Tibet. Hence, avoidance of the b-word: understood either as bod, the Tibetan term for Tibet, or as bho攷션, the Nepali racial epithet derived from it. At issue here, for activist and academic alike, is the assertion of ethnic and cultural autonomy. But both sides representations of the Tamang are weakened by this minimalisation of the b-dimension. In particular, the contention of this study is that the limitations they both impose make it impossible to fully understand Tamang percept

Understanding BAM A. What does BAM mean? B. Biblical Value of BAM C. The purpose of BAM II. The Importance and Challenges to Incorporating the BAM in Nepal A. The Importance of BAM B. The Challenges to Incorporate the BAM III. The way of incorporating BAM IV. Implication Conclusion ... Read more Related papers Religion and Secularism in Contemporary Nepal Chiara Letizia , David Gellner Routledge Handbook of South Asian Religions, 2021 Between 2006 and 2017 Nepal transitioned from being an officially Hindu kingdom to an officially secular federal republican state. Although some Nepalis have upheld a model of secularism that would imply no connection between the state and religion, for most it implies that the state should support all religions equally. Through case studies (1) of conversion and the relation of Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity to the state and to Hinduism, (2) of diverse Hindu responses to secularism, and (3) of the controversy over animal sacrifices at the Gadhimai festival, the chapter examines the effects of the new concepts, propagated by the state especially since 2015, of secularism and of distinct religions and ethnic groups. download Download free PDF View PDF chevron_right Banishment of the B-word: interpreting ethnic and religious revival among the Tamang people of Nepal Jonathan Samuels European Bulletin of Himalayan Research (EBHR), 2018 Since 1990, an ethnic revival (Toffin 209: 25) in Nepal has seen members of janaj캐ti (indigenous nationalities) campaign for greater recognition and rights for their respective groups. Many anthropologists are strongly opposed to the way that activists project the identities of these groups as historical continuities. Questions about the antiquity and authenticity of their cultural and religious traditions also abound. The focus of this study are the Tamang, one of Nepals largest ethnic minorities. Recent changes in Tamang religious practices are considered within the context of the contemporaneous ethnic revival. After outlining the historical background of the current situation, in which some activists and anthropologists find themselves pitted against one another, this study argues that members of both groups are strangely united in their wish to distance representations of Tamang identity and religious affiliation from associations with Tibet. Hence, avoidance of the b-word: understood either as bod, the Tibetan term for Tibet, or as bho攷션, the Nepali racial epithet derived from it. At issue here, for activist and academic alike, is the assertion of ethnic and cultural autonomy. But both sides representations of the Tamang are weakened by this minimalisation of the b-dimension. In particular, the contention of this study is that the limitations they both impose make it impossible to fully understand Tamang perceptions of their own cultural heritage or the background and nature of contemporary changes occurring within their religious traditions. download Download free PDF

{"source_url": "", "title": "Capabilities", "text": "Capabilities 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Home About Us Capabilities Projects Innovation Publications Advisory Careers Contact More Home About Us Capabilities Projects Innovation Publications Advisory Careers Contact Home About Us Capabilities Projects Innovation Publications Advisory Careers Contact Our Capabilities Health Policy Research Health Policy Research Health Policy Research Our goal is to advance health decision making processes towards a firmer evidential base specifically to promote health system performance and accountability . AIHP partners with others to conduct research and analysis on the major elements of health policy as a key ingredient for effective decision making and implementation. Engaging policy makers and practitioners in substantially shaping discourse to fill a critical need in a forward looking and pragmatic agenda to improve health. Data Analytics Health Policy Research Health Policy Research At AIHP, we are confident that careful examination of data can yield useful insights to catalyze innovations and drive improvements in the healthcare ecosystem. Our expertise in data analytics is brought to bear in assisting our partners identify opportunities to optimize healthcare delivery and catalyze social impact in communities. We embrace a robust analytical framework that triangulates data from different sources to provide critical information and insights for decision making. Technical Advisory Health Policy Research Educational and Training Services Our advisory services are underpinned on strong research and evidence generation procedures that employ the most current and best in class analytical methods in health metrics and evaluation. We maintain a practical and adaptable flair suitable for dynamic and complex settings. Leveraging a multidisciplinary skillset, AIHP is well positioned and has proven capabilities to create value in different aspects of the healthcare delivery models geared towards social impact. Educational and Training Services Incubation of Novel Health Technologies Educational and Training Services We recognize that it is impossible to implement sound health programs without a pool of well-trained personnel. To this end, we partner with different organizations to design and develop relevant training and mentoring programs that meet their strategic organizational priorities. For successful execution, we leverage our comparative advantages and of our partners to offer practical training in critical areas of the health system, with a specific focus on data analytics and innovation management. Our bespoke trainings are well suited for key decisionmakers and implementers, including executives, health system managers and frontline health workers at different levels. Incubation of Novel Health Technologies Incubation of Novel Health Technologies Incubation of Novel Health Technologies AIHP collaborates with changemakers to catalyze innovations aimed at building health system capacity and scale up of impactful health and community interventions. Our efforts are ambitious, but our resources limited. Therefore, we believe that sustainable impactful change should and will happen through collaboration. By bringing together various stakeholders within a community building framework; expertise and talent will drive creative interventions and solutions. The first Summit of this type was held in Mozambique on the 10th October 2013 in partnership with the University St. Thomas of Mozambique. Find out more Strategic Information Solutions Incubation of Novel Health Technologies Incubation of Novel Health Technologies We provide strategic monitoring, evaluation and research capabilities, vital for successful implementation of health and social investment programs. Through a pool of experienced experts who have worked together in different countries in Africa, our teams are primed to deliver. We have the capacity to design and undertake complex data collection projects, as well as leverage secondary data sources to rigorously measure the impact of social and health programs in communities. Through our educational and training activities, we strive to train and mentor future leaders in the field of monitoring and evaluation. Copyright  2024 Africa Institute for Health Policy - All Rights Reserved. Privacy Policy Terms and Conditions
